summary: An inspiring TEDx talk by Joe Justice discussing Team Wikispeed's innovative approach to building ultra-efficient cars through agile methodology.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man in a white shirt standing on a stage, holding a remote control, and speaking to an audience. The background includes a painting with a pink and blue sky. The man is identified as Joe Justice, and the video showcases an orange sports car with black stripes, displaying its efficiency metrics: 104 MPG in the city, 114 MPG on the highway, and 158 MPG Imperial, 1.5 L/100KM. The video also highlights a manufacturing process, showing a metal mold with a shiny, silver-colored object inside, accompanied by the text, "If an engineer found a better design tomorrow, they would need to wait 10 years." The video emphasizes the importance of efficiency and innovation in design and manufacturing.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with the sound of a car engine starting and idling, creating an ambient background suggestive of a vehicle or garage setting. The engine fades out as a male speaker enthusiastically begins with the claim, "My next car gets 100 miles per gallon," and introduces himself as Joe Justice, a software consultant and member of Team Wiki Speed. In a professional, informative tone, he describes Team Wiki Speed's accomplishment of building a fast, affordable, efficient, and safe commuter car, noting the functional prototype's rapid construction in three months. A brief pause marks a shift to addressing how this is possible, given the slow rate of change in existing car designs, noting a six-year period resulting in only a 2 mile-per-gallon improvement. The speaker attributes this slowness to the high cost of changing manufacturing processes, noting the long investment periods for existing designs. The speaker states that these long development cycles are common in manufacturing teams.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man in a white shirt and dark pants standing on a stage, speaking into a microphone and holding a remote control. He is presenting in front of a dark background with a lamp and a screen displaying a sunset image. The presentation includes a slide titled "AGILE: NEW SOFTWARE TEAMS," which shows a circular diagram with stages like "DESIGN," "IMPLEMENTATION," "VERIFICATION," and "MAINTENANCE," along with a note stating, "New products are based on: what we believed the customer wanted, 7 days ago." The scene transitions to a man in a beige suit and orange tie standing at a podium with a microphone, in front of a banner reading "AUTOMOTIVE XPRIZE 100MPGe." The video then shows a blue, aerodynamic vehicle with a Shell logo, labeled "LUDINGTON STATE UNIVERSITY," navigating through a parking lot marked with orange cones. The video returns to the man on stage, continuing his presentation with the same background and attire.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker discussing the differences between "old software teams" and "new software teams", noting that "new software teams" run on seven-day development cycles, allowing "changes very quickly." He then mentions the "Progressive Insurance Automotive X Prize" of 2008 and a "ten million dollar prize purse" intended to challenge whether building 100-mile-per-gallon cars to "road legal safety specifications" was possible. He mentions that "the closest thing we had in 2008 were like bobsleds," which could achieve the mileage but had one occupant and did not meet legal requirements.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man in a white shirt and dark pants standing on a stage, speaking into a microphone and gesturing with his hands. The background is dark, with a lamp and a screen displaying a colorful image. The scene transitions to an outdoor setting, showcasing a unique, futuristic-looking car with a transparent dome and orange accents, driving on a road surrounded by greenery. The video then returns to the man on stage, continuing his presentation. The scene shifts again to a group of people in orange shirts standing next to a bright orange car with the number "11" on it, in a parking lot with a building and a sign in the background. The text "BUILT IN 3 MONTHS" appears on the screen, indicating the car's rapid construction. The video concludes with the man on stage, still speaking and gesturing, with the same dark background and lamp visible.
events_list.audio_caption: A single male speaker with an enthusiastic and storytelling tone narrates an experience joining the X Prize. He started alone, began blogging, and eventually gathered a team through social networking.  He describes how within three months, they created a car for the X Prize with a volunteer team, and tied for tenth place, surpassing over a hundred other cars.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man standing on a stage, dressed in a white shirt with black stripes, holding a remote control in his right hand. He appears to be giving a presentation, as he is wearing a headset microphone. The background is dark, with a white lampshade visible on the right side of the frame. The scene then transitions to a workshop where a group of people, all wearing orange shirts, are working on a car. One person is lying on top of the car, while others are assisting with tools and equipment. The text "ITERATE THE ENTIRE CAR IN HOURS" appears at the bottom of the frame, emphasizing the efficiency and speed of the work being done. The video then returns to the man on stage, who continues his presentation, gesturing with his left hand while holding the remote control in his right. The background remains dark, with the white lampshade still visible on the right side of the frame. The man appears to be speaking, as his mouth is slightly open in some frames. The video concludes with the man still on stage, continuing his presentation, with the same dark background and white lampshade visible.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a single male speaker describing how his team uses techniques with "funny sounding names," like "Agile, Lean, and Scrum" to make changes quickly, his tone is informative. Following this, a distinct "beep" sound effect is heard.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man standing on a stage, dressed in a light-colored, striped button-up shirt, holding a remote control in his right hand. He is wearing a headset microphone, indicating he is likely giving a presentation or speech. The background is dark, with a white lampshade visible to the right, suggesting a formal or professional setting. The scene then transitions to an exterior shot of a building with a large banner that reads "North American International Auto Show January 15-23," indicating the location is likely a venue for an auto show event. The building has a modern architectural design with a geometric facade. The video then returns to the man on stage, who continues to speak, gesturing with his left hand while holding the remote control in his right. The atmosphere remains professional, and the man appears engaged in his presentation. The video concludes with the man still on stage, maintaining his posture and focus, suggesting a continuous and coherent presentation.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker sharing an anecdote, recalling an invitation to an auto show following a competition win. He mentions the desire for a more aesthetically pleasing car and the expensive and time-consuming process of creating one. In response, he took time off work to attend composite school. The clip ends with a sound effect, which seems to be a door slamming.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man standing on a stage, dressed in a light-colored, striped button-up shirt, holding a remote control in his right hand. He appears to be giving a presentation, as indicated by his gestures and the presence of a microphone headset. The background is dark, with a white lampshade visible on the right side of the frame. The scene transitions to a computer-generated image of a sleek, futuristic car, showcasing its design and features. The car is displayed in a 3D model, with green lines and axes indicating its dimensions and orientation. The video then shifts to a real-life setting, showing a car exhibition booth with the text "DUB SHOW LIVE" prominently displayed on banners. The booth features a sleek, futuristic car with a dark gray body and red accents, surrounded by other vehicles and people engaged in conversation. The atmosphere is lively, with bright lighting and a high ceiling, typical of a convention center. The video returns to the man on stage, continuing his presentation with expressive hand movements and a confident demeanor. The audience is shown in the next frame, seated and attentively watching the presentation, with some individuals taking notes or holding drinks. The video concludes with the man on stage, still holding the remote control and gesturing, emphasizing his points to the audience. The overall atmosphere is professional and engaging, with a focus on the presentation and the futuristic car showcased in the exhibition.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip begins with a male speaker resuming a story, detailing the construction of car models and a composite process. He explains that they were able to build their car body in "structural carbon fiber in three days for $800". Laughter and applause follow, then the speaker expresses appreciation, stating, "You guys are awesome. Thanks so much." He continues his narrative, explaining that they were placed on the main floor of an auto show "between Ford and Chevrolet". He describes the car as "beautiful".

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man standing on a stage, dressed in a white shirt and black pants, holding a remote control in his right hand. He appears to be giving a presentation, as he gestures with his left hand while speaking. The background is dark, with a white lampshade visible on the right side of the frame. The scene then transitions to an outdoor setting where a man in an orange shirt and cap is seated in a black race car, surrounded by people, including a cameraman filming the scene. The car has various sponsor logos, such as "Honda Racing" and "Wikispeed." The video then returns to the stage, where the man continues his presentation, with a large screen behind him displaying the outdoor scene with the race car. The audience is visible in the foreground, attentively watching the presentation. The video concludes with a close-up of the man on stage, emphasizing his gestures and expressions as he continues to speak.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip starts with a male speaker listing media outlets, including "the Discovery Channel, Popular Science, Popular Mechanics, the New York Times Online, the National Geographic Channel, Wired Magazine, the Forbes Billionaire Club." He continues, explaining that the topics he's discussing happened in a six-month period.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man standing on a stage, dressed in a white shirt with black trim, speaking into a microphone attached to his ear. He gestures with his hands as he addresses the audience, with a dark background and a white lampshade visible behind him. The scene transitions to a workshop where a man in a dark shirt and khaki pants is working on a white car model labeled "CONVERTIBLE CITY CAR" in orange text. The man is seen smoothing the surface of the car model, which is placed on a workbench surrounded by tools and equipment. The video then returns to the man on stage, continuing his presentation with hand gestures. A diagram labeled "MODULARITY" appears, showing an orange car model with various components labeled, such as "DRIVE TRAIN MODULE," "AEROSHELL," "INTERIOR MODULE," "CHASSIS," "PEDAL PLATE," "FRONT CRUSH STRUCTURE," "SUSPENSION MODULE," and "REAR CRUSH STRUCTURE." The man continues to speak and gesture, emphasizing his points. The video concludes with the man still on stage, maintaining his engaging presentation style.
events_list.audio_caption: A male speaker describes Rob Moorebacker leading the German town, Maryland team, producing a convertible city car mold. He then explains the car's modular design, with an engine swappable from gasoline to electric as quickly as changing a tire, and a car body switchable from convertible to pickup truck. The speaker speaks clearly and enthusiastically.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man standing on a stage, dressed in a light-colored, striped shirt, holding a remote control, and speaking into a microphone. The background is dark, with a white lampshade visible on the right side. The scene transitions to a 3D model of a car, showcasing its internal structure and components, including the chassis, wheels, and seating area. The man continues to speak on stage, gesturing with his hands to emphasize his points. The audience is shown attentively listening, with some individuals smiling and others taking notes. The video then shifts to a workshop setting, where a person is working on a car frame, surrounded by various tools and equipment. The text "LEAN: USE LESS STUFF" appears on the screen, highlighting the concept of lean manufacturing. The man on stage continues his presentation, with the audience remaining engaged. The scene transitions back to the workshop, where a group of people is filming a person in a red shirt, with the text "AGILE: REDUCE COST TO MAKE CHANGE" displayed, emphasizing the agile methodology. The video concludes with the man on stage, still speaking and gesturing, maintaining the focus on his presentation.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a single male speaker describing a car chassis, emphasizing its lightness and safety rating. He speaks in a confident and informative tone, followed by applause and appreciative shouts from an audience. He expresses gratitude. He then shifts to discussing safety test designs and a test-driven development process, again met with audience approval. He discusses less stuff being used, detailing how a high school graduate builds a WikiSpeed car with affordable equipment compared to expensive automotive processes. He then discusses reducing costs in tooling, machinery, and complexity, which enables changes to any part of the car every seven days. Lastly, he talks about distributed collaborative teams. The speaker emphasizes that "morality is a multiplier for velocity."

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a scene of an audience seated in a lecture hall, attentively listening to a speaker. The audience members are dressed in casual attire, with some holding notebooks or electronic devices, indicating an educational or professional setting. The focus then shifts to a man standing on a stage, wearing a light-colored, striped shirt and a headset microphone, suggesting he is the speaker. The background is dark, with a white lampshade visible, emphasizing the speaker's presence. The scene transitions to a workshop environment where individuals in red shirts are working on a large, black vehicle with the text "SCRUM: ROLES AND RESPONSIBILITIES" displayed on the screen, indicating a discussion or demonstration related to Scrum methodology in project management. The workshop is filled with tools, equipment, and posters, creating a busy and industrious atmosphere. The video then returns to the speaker on stage, who continues to address the audience, maintaining the focus on his presentation. The overall narrative suggests a professional development event, combining theoretical discussion with practical application.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a single male speaker describing how his teams are organized. He mentions it's "the smallest fastest way to organize an agile team," and calls it "Scrum," a method for managing a team in a rapid way. He describes that his teams are managed in "Team Wiki speed."

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man standing on a stage, wearing a light-colored, striped button-up shirt and a headset microphone. He holds a remote control in his right hand and appears to be giving a presentation, gesturing with his left hand. The background is dark, with a white lampshade visible on the right side of the frame. The scene then transitions to a workshop setting where two men are working on an engine. One man is wearing an orange long-sleeve shirt, and the other is in a checkered shirt. They are focused on the engine, with the text "XP: PAIRING AND SWARMING" displayed on the screen, indicating a discussion about Extreme Programming practices. The workshop is busy, with other individuals working in the background. The video then returns to the man on stage, who continues his presentation, using hand gestures to emphasize his points. The background remains dark, with the white lampshade still visible. The video concludes with the man still on stage, maintaining his presentation style.
events_list.audio_caption: The clip features a male speaker who discusses a collaborative work environment, stating "we do all our work in pairs" to avoid training and documentation needs. He illustrates this with an example of two colleagues, "Martin Val and Kurt Roy," building an engine together, sharing knowledge in real-time. The overall tone is informative.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man in a light-colored, striped shirt and a headset microphone, standing on a stage and delivering a presentation. He holds a remote control in his right hand and gestures with his left hand as he speaks. The background is dark, with a white lampshade visible on the right side of the frame. The man appears to be addressing an audience, likely discussing topics related to workflow visualization and the benefits of using modern tools. The presentation includes slides with text such as "VISUALIZING WORKFLOW AVOIDS HIDDEN DELAYS" and "THESE TOOLS DID NOT EXIST 10 YEARS AGO," accompanied by images of various logos, including LinkedIn, Dropbox, Google Docs, and YouTube. The video also shows a collage of images representing different industries, such as insurance, finance, automotive, manufacturing, entertainment, healthcare, government, and energy, with the text "Scrum Masters & Agile Teams Needed" displayed above them. The man continues to speak and gesture throughout the video, emphasizing his points and engaging with the audience.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio begins with a single male speaker describing a workflow visualization process. He emphasizes that the necessary tools are free and recently available, suggesting a novel approach. The speaker believes that nearly every industry benefits from this process, and it may become necessary for businesses to compete in the future. He finishes the statement by asking a rhetorical question, "So what to do?"

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man standing on a stage, dressed in a white shirt with black accents, delivering a presentation. He is equipped with a headset microphone, indicating he is addressing an audience. The background is dark, with a white screen visible to the right, suggesting a professional setting, possibly a conference or seminar. The man uses hand gestures to emphasize his points, occasionally looking to his left, possibly engaging with the audience or referring to notes. The presentation includes a slide titled "INCREASE CUSTOMER VISIBLE VALUE," which outlines a cyclical process involving "REQUIREMENTS," "DESIGN," "IMPLEMENTATION," "VERIFICATION," and "MAINTENANCE," with arrows indicating the flow between these stages. The slide also mentions that the product is re-invented with customer feedback every 7 days, emphasizing a continuous improvement cycle. The man continues to speak, maintaining a focused and professional demeanor throughout the presentation.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio features a male speaker offering instructions to different types of listeners: business owners, team members, and process coaches. He suggests tasks tailored to each role, such as identifying a process coach for the business, asking process coaches for efficiency improvements, or identifying a company's value stream map. His tone is encouraging and instructional.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a man standing on a stage, dressed in a white shirt with black trim, holding a remote control in his right hand. He appears to be giving a presentation, as indicated by his posture and the presence of a microphone headset. The background is dark, with a lamp visible to the right, suggesting a formal setting, possibly a conference or lecture hall. The man's facial expressions and body language indicate he is actively engaging with his audience, likely explaining or discussing a topic. The scene then transitions to an indoor exhibition space, showcasing a bright orange sports car prominently displayed in the foreground. The car is sleek and modern, with a convertible design, and is positioned on a reflective floor, enhancing its visual appeal. In the background, various aircraft are suspended from the ceiling, including a small yellow plane and a larger white and red plane, indicating the exhibition's theme may be related to aviation or technology. The environment is well-lit, with a high ceiling and industrial-style architecture, creating a spacious and professional atmosphere. The video effectively contrasts the formal presentation setting with the dynamic and visually striking exhibition space, highlighting the diverse contexts in which the man might be involved.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker inquiring about "WikiSpeed's" next steps. The speaker then provides an overview of their organization, mentioning they have "more than 100 volunteers in eight countries now," and that they "sell cars now." The speaker has a confident and informative speaking tone.

events_list.video_caption: The video begins with a scene inside a spacious hangar, showcasing an orange sports car prominently displayed in the foreground. The hangar is filled with various aircraft, including a small plane hanging from the ceiling and a larger jet positioned on the right side. The background features a large mural depicting a sky with clouds, adding to the aviation theme. The scene transitions to a man standing on a stage, dressed in a light-colored, striped shirt and dark pants, speaking to an audience. He is equipped with a headset microphone, indicating he is giving a presentation. The stage is set with a red carpet, and a large screen behind him displays images related to the hangar and the sports car. The audience is visible in the foreground, attentively watching the presentation. The man continues to speak, gesturing with his hands to emphasize his points. The screen behind him changes to display a message that reads, "KEEP UP THE AWESOME!!" followed by "THE SOCIAL GOOD" and an email address, encouraging the audience to stay engaged and contribute to a social cause. The video concludes with the man still on stage, holding a remote control, likely used to navigate through his presentation slides. The overall atmosphere is professional and focused, with the man engaging the audience through his speech and visual aids.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip starts with a male speaker discussing using processes to "solve bigger problems", specifically mentioning eradicating polio and developing low-cost medical centers for developing communities. He then humorously pauses with a "cough" before continuing to encourage joining Team Wiki Speed to "change the world" and sharpen agile skills. After a short encouragement about making a difference in the world, he invites everyone to spend two hours a day or week rapidly solving problems for social good.

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man standing on a stage, wearing a white shirt with black stripes and a headset microphone. He is actively engaging with the audience, using hand gestures to emphasize his points. The background is dark, with a white screen visible to the right, suggesting a presentation setting. The audience, seated in a tiered arrangement, is attentively watching the speaker. The room is well-lit, with warm lighting fixtures on the walls, creating a professional and focused atmosphere. The man's expressions and gestures indicate he is delivering a speech or lecture, maintaining a dynamic and engaging presence throughout the video.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio features a single male speaker, sounding enthusiastic. He shares details about Team Wiki Speed, noting that members "spend between two and eight hours a week helping us rapidly develop our cars" with "phenomenal and regular successes". He adds that they "build ultra efficient cars," and the listener "might help eradicate rotavirus or develop simple, maintainable distributed banking applications for the developing world." Then he says, "And that might be even cooler than watching TV or coaching Little League."

events_list.video_caption: The video features a man in a white shirt with a microphone headset, standing on a stage and delivering a speech. The background is dark, with a white screen to his right. The man appears to be addressing an audience, as he gestures with his hands and shifts his stance. The scene transitions to a graphic with the text "KEEP UP THE AWESOME!! RAPIDLY SOLVE PROBLEMS FOR SOCIAL GOOD." (Keep up the awesome! Quickly solve problems for the benefit of society) in bold letters, accompanied by an illustration of a gorilla and a shark. The video then returns to the man on stage, who continues to speak and engage with the audience. The audience is shown clapping and cheering, indicating their appreciation for the speaker's presentation. The video concludes with a black screen displaying the text "TEDxRainier" and the website "tedxrainer.com," indicating that the event is a TEDxRainier independently organized TED event.
events_list.audio_caption: The audio clip begins with a male speaker stating that if everyone in the room spent two hours a week rapidly solving problems, it would be "so awesome". He follows this by exclaiming it would be "like a gorilla high-fiving a shark in front of an explosion." The speech is delivered in an energetic and enthusiastic tone. The speaker then says, "Thank you very much," followed by a crescendo of clapping sounds, suggesting applause from an audience.
